NewsLine.NewsLineText: HEALTH-CHINA-AIDS:China hospitals demand waivers for blood - staff

body.p: BEIJING, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Some Chinese hospitals are demanding waivers from patients needing blood transfusions to prevent lawsuits over infection with HIV and other viruses, hospital staff said on Monday.
A Ministry of Health official told Reuters patients had to sign waivers for special or experimental procedures under new regulations issued on September 1, but not for normal blood transfusions.

However, staff at two hospitals in Beijing said waivers for blood transfusions were common practice since the regulations put the burden of proof on hospitals to establish they were not responsible for medical accidents.

The risk of infection from tainted blood in China was highlighted last year by a scandal in which thousands of people in the central province of Henan were infected with HIV when they sold plasma to illegal blood banks.
The blood banks mixed up the samples, extracted the valuable plasma and then pumped the mixed residue back into the donors.

At the Peking University First Hospital, patients had to sign a waiver explaining that blood had been screened twice but there was still a slight risk of infection from HIV and other viruses which had an incubation period, a member of staff said.
"If they do not sign, we do not give them a blood transfusion," said the official from the hospital's blood disease department.
"Generally, every hospital has this practice and it happens not just in Beijing but in other cities," she said. "It is required by health authorities."
The hospital would also test the recipient for HIV and other viruses before a blood transfusion and keep a sample of the blood given to protect itself against claims, she said.
At the Tongren hospital in Beijing, a doctor in the blood disease ward said patients had to sign similar documents.
"There are different kinds of waivers," she said. "Patients are required to sign a waiver for blood transfusions and it includes items like HIV and hepatitis."
However the Health Ministry official, in the medical service department that oversees hospitals, denied waivers existed.
"We have not heard reports of waivers for HIV and hepatitis infection from blood transfusions," she said. "This could never happen."
"The new regulations require patients to sign waivers that exempt hospitals from responsibility for special checks and treatment, operations and experimental medical treatment."

This month, Chinese government health officials revised their official estimate of the size of the HIV-positive population from 850,000 to nearly one million. HIV cases rose 16.7 percent on the year in the first half of 2002.
The United Nations has said the number of Chinese HIV infections could rise to 10 million if no effective countermeasures are taken.
The sensitivity of the issue was illustrated this month by the detention of prominent AIDS activists Wan Yanhai for several weeks for leaking an official report on the Henan scandal.
China said on Friday it had released Wan after he confessed to leaking state secrets.
